entry.title: Re: Accessing deployed SAP Build Apps app in SAP Public C...
entry.content:
Hi @Filip_Polak 

Thank you for that question. I will walk through some details about Build Apps:

  • Pleae note, SAP Build Apps are deployed to SAP BTP as stand alone HTML5 apps. They are not placed in Work Zone unless you configure them to be.
  • However, you can access them from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via a custom tile in the Launchpad, which opens the app in a new window.
  • Embedding Build Apps directly in the S/4HANA Public Cloud Launchpad shell is not currently supported due to SAP’s content security and clean-core principles.
  • Build Apps is suitable for side-by-side apps, especially when combined with SAP BTP destinations to securely consume S/4HANA APIs.

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: subcontracting with rm sold and invoiced
entry.content:
Hi,

I have a case where our company produces flour. We are sub-contracting pasta making to a supplier where he will be using our flour but due to regulation, we have to issue an invoice for the quantity of flour to be used for pasta production.

in SAP, the subcontracting PO process consider transferring the flour to the supplier without issuing any invoice (flour will still be  owned by our company). 

Also, this same supplier is also a customer that is buying flour for his own consumption.

My questions are:

1- how to process a subcontracting PO where part of the BoM (flour) is sold and invoiced? is it possible?

2- in order to differentiate the customer from supplier, we consider creating another BP number for the same customer name but defined as customer and supplier in order to track the sold flour and the purchased finished good (pasta). Does this make sense?

3- From accounting perspective, how should I treat the transactions (POs and invoices, payments...), shoudl I create different GL accounts for the different BP numbers?

Appreciate your help on this

entry.title: Re: where to download SAP wen ide?
entry.content:
Hi @swswswswsws 

Thank you for your question.

SAP Web IDE has been officially retired and replaced by more modern tools like SAP Business Application Studio on SAP BTP. As of recent, SAP no longer offers Web IDE for download or deployment, and it is not legally available via mirrors or third-party sites, as it’s proprietary software.

Note, if your company previously downloaded the personal edition it may still be available under your SAP S-user. You can reach it via https://support.sap.com/en/my-support/software-downloads.html

Note that SAP has removed most Web IDE versions and it's very unlikely you’ll find it unless your account had legacy entitlements. If your project critically depends on  specific SAP Web IDE  you can request for temporary access if it was once licensed under your account. For this you will need to open a ticket with SAP.

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Consume SAP Data Warehouse Cloud in Power BI
entry.content:
@thomasrohmann1 I did find a workaround to this... It turns out that database user's can in fact be maintained within a DAC in SAP Datasphere... In your permissions table where you define the authorization values for your Data Access Controls instead of giving the User ID as your email address simply replace this with the Database Users username... You must add the entire user name "SPACE#USER". Then you can just assign authorizations to this DB user as you would a application user.

I hope this makes sense... But please feel free to drop me a private message if you would like additional clarity.

entry.title: Re: Extract data from S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition using...
entry.content:
Hello @Magesh07 

Yes, in SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, you can export table-level data using the following options:

  • Fiori App Exports – Most list reports allow export to Excel, CSV, PDF, or Google Sheets via the “Export As” option.
  • Customer Data Browser App – Lets you view and export data from whitelisted tables (limited to released views or business objects).
  • Google Sheets Integration – You can export UI table data directly to Google Sheets using SAP BTP (requires setup).

You can go through below SAP Helpful documentations

How to Export Data-SAP Help 

Can I download tables directly from S/4HANA public cloud?  

Export SAP UI Tables from SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition to Google Sheets 

Best regards,
Chuma

entry.title: Re: Request for Information About Getting a SAP License f...
entry.content:
Hello @fahmi_bargui 

Thank you for reaching out, and I appreciate your patience.

I understand how important it is to have the SAP software available in time for the academic year. Since you've already submitted your requests via email and the SAP Academic Alliance's portal without a response,

Fellow below Step-by-Step Escalation Process

1. Resend with URGENT in the Subject Line

Re-send your original email to the following addresses and mark it as urgent:

  • sapnextgen@sap.com
  • webmaster@sap.com
  • universityalliances@sap.com (this is the official University Alliances contact)

Subject example:
URGENT: Follow-up on SAP Educational License Request for University, No Response Since July 30

Attach your previous email(s) and mention it’s your second or third follow-up.
2. Use the SAP University Alliances Contact Form Again

Try this link again and fill the contact form, clearly noting that your earlier submissions received no reply:
https://www.sap.com/about/company/innovation/next-gen-innovation-platform.html#contact

Also visit https://support.sap.com/en/contact-us.html ,you can call, chat or Email SAP 

In the message section you can add:

This is a follow-up submission. I submitted this form previously on (Insert date) and have not received a reply. The academic semester is starting shortly, and access to SAP software is urgently needed for coursework.

Make sure that your university is officially listed as a partner or applicant with the SAP University Alliances program. You can also explore this link for further guidance
https://sap.com/academic

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: What Procurement Gets Wrong About Supplier Onboarding
entry.content:
Let’s talk about supplier onboarding. It sounds simple, right? Send a form, get the answers, approve the supplier, move on. But in my years working with procurement teams using SAP Ariba, especially Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (SLP), I’ve noticed a pattern: onboarding is often treated like a checkbox. A one-time event. A necessary evil to “get them in the system.” And when that’s the mindset, a few things tend to go wrong.

Think of onboarding as setting up a new contact in your phone. You could just enter the name and number and call it a day. But if you take a minute to add their company, title, email, maybe a note about how you met, you’ll thank yourself later. Ask me how I know - my phone is full of contacts like “Tree guy Rick."

It’s the same with suppliers. Capturing clean, complete data at the start — banking details, diversity certifications, tax IDs, ownership structure, the right ANID — helps you avoid messy corrections downstream.  You have the tools to do this well:  questionnaires, approval workflows, ERP integrations. But the tech only works if the process behind it is thoughtful.


Red Flag #1: “We’ll Fix It Later”

I hear this a lot when customers are in a rush, or creating suppliers reactively. The supplier needs to be paid or onboarded quickly, so teams bypass the formal process or enter placeholder info. The problem? Those workarounds tend to become permanent. Later on, when you’re trying to route a risk assessment or requalify the supplier, suddenly nothing lines up because the foundational data was never right to begin with.


Red Flag #2: Confusing the Supplier

“If we send them the form, they’ll figure it out.”  Like Field of Dreams, but for Ariba. Unfortunately it doesn’t always go the way you hope. Suppliers often get multiple invites from different buying organizations. They might not know which Business Network ID (ANID) to use, how to log in, or why the questions look different for every customer. If your process isn’t clear, suppliers get frustrated and either abandon the form or call your AP help desk in a panic. 

(Shameless self-promotion, my colleague Trusha and I actually did a webinar on this exact topic - click HERE to watch it on-demand 😊)


Red Flag #3: Treating All Suppliers the Same

Do your onboarding steps reflect actually reflect what you need from the supplier? Or is a local landscaping company going through the same full workflow as a multinational logistics provider?  Many of our customers use the Supplier Request to discern one type from another, the most common being suppliers that are only being invited for an RFP vs. those that are being invited to fully onboard and transact.  If you're using SLP today, you already have the ability to configure onboarding by supplier type, region, category, etc. If you’re not doing that yet, you might be overloading small suppliers with unnecessary requirements, or even under-scrutinizing those with higher risk exposure.


Onboarding Is Strategy, Not Admin

Here’s the shift: onboarding isn’t just an admin task. It’s a strategic step that sets the tone for your supplier relationships, ensures compliance, and enables automation and insight downstream. And when done well, it actually makes everyone's life easier — from sourcing to accounts payable to the suppliers themselves.

If your onboarding process feels clunky, inconsistent, or like it’s creating more work than it saves, you’re not alone. But there’s a better way. Taking time to revisit your approach can have a huge downstream impact. Let’s stop treating onboarding like a hurdle. Instead, let’s make it inviting, like a welcome mat.

entry.title: Re: Organizational Change: Mass Change Profit Center Assi...
entry.content:
Hi Marie,

If you’re referring to the S/4HANA Public Cloud version, currently there is no dedicated app available for maintaining Cost Centers in bulk. However, a workaround is available via form of API for Cost Centers, which can be used to handle mass maintenance scenarios (see Cost Center documentation).

For Profit Centers, there is already a dedicated application Edit Profit Centers - Collective, and also an API for Profit Centers available to support integration or automation use cases (see Profit Center documentation).

Lastly, there is ongoing user research focused on new mass changes application for both Cost and Profit Centers. If you're interested in contributing or sharing your experience/needs/thoughts with our research team, feel free to reach out – research team would really appreciate your input.

I hope this helps!

Best regards,
Radovan Tanac
Product Manager
S/4HANA Public Cloud

entry.title: Re: Issue Granting Access to Users Imported from Starter...
entry.content:
Greetings @oquijano0327 !

To directly address your question:

In particular, does the column labeled “Connected” have any impact on whether the users can access the system? Only System Administartor user appears as “Yes” in that field, while the others show no value.

Not exactly. The “Connected” column (which is actually labeled "Logged on") indicates whether the user account in the starter system is logged into the S/4HANA starter system at that time. If that column is empty, it means that the user is not currently logged into the system.

As such, the most probable causes that need to be checked would be:

  1. User Activation in IAS:

    • Make sure the users validated their access via the activation email sent from IAS.

    • If activation emails weren’t sent, go to IAS and manually trigger the email by resending or reimporting.

  2. Missing Home URL:

    • Ensure the Home URL for the S/4HANA Starter System is maintained in IAS for the relevant application. Without this, users won’t get the correct system link in the email.

  3. Wrong User Name Format:

    • Double-check that the User Name in the Starter System is exactly the same as the Login Name in IAS, including casing and special characters.

  4. Reimport Might Help:

    • Try re-downloading the user data from the Maintain Business Users app and re-importing it into IAS with the “Download for IDP” format to ensure everything syncs correctly.

 

The following steps, which are present in the help portal (Create a Business User in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition | SAP Help Portal) and (How to Maintain Business Users | SAP Help Portal) should be made to add users to the starter system:

  1. Launch the Manage Workforce app.

  2. Go to Import -> Worker.

  3. Set the delimiter to Comma (,) and click Download Templates.

  4. Save and open the template in Microsoft Excel.

  5. Fill out the following fields for each team member:

    • WorkerID: Use the same value as the User ID in IAS

    • UserName: Must match the Login Name in IAS

    • WorkerType: Enter BUP003

    • Start Date: Use today’s date in YYYYMMDD format

    • End Date: Enter 99991231

  6. Import it using the Manage Workforce app.

 

The CSV file needs to be UTF-8-encoded and must comply with the following pattern:

 

User Name

User ID (Optional)

E-Mail (Optional)Global User ID (Optional)Role ID

<User name 1>

<Business user ID 1>

<Business user's mail address 1><Global user ID 1><Business role ID 1>

<User name 2>

<Business user ID 2>

<Business user's mail address 2><Global user ID 2><Business role ID 2>

<User name 3>

<Business user ID 3>

<Business user's mail address 3><Global user ID 3><Business role ID 3>

<User name n>

<Business user ID n>

<Business user's mail address n><Global user ID n>

<Business role ID n>

 
 
In the app, you are provided with a CSV template that you can download and use for filling in the user role assignments. When uploading the CSV file, you can decide if you want to add the role assignments to a user, or if you want to overwrite them completely.

You can find the CSV template as follows: Click the Upload button, then click Upload User Role Assignments in the menu that appears. This opens a dialog box containing the Download CSV Template link that you can use to download the template.

The user ID is optional. Only if the user name is not unique, the user ID has to be maintained.

Once the users are added, assign the Administrator role in order for them to be able to manage their own access and create test users. To efficiently assign the same role to multiple users:

  1. Go to the Maintain Business Roles app.

  2. Select the Administrator role (BR_ADMINISTRATOR).

  3. Click Edit, then open the Assigned Business Users tab.

  4. Click Add, select the checkboxes for all relevant users.

Check that each user has an assigned Launchpad Space on the corresponding tab. If none is assigned, click Add and choose Create Spaces Based on SAP-Delivered Spaces, as this duplicates the default SAP layout associated with the Administrator role. After that, the IT Contact should download the user list along with their assigned roles:

  1. Go to the Maintain Business Users app and select all relevant users.

  2. Choose Download -> Download for IDP and save the file in CSV format.

  3. In IAS, open the Import Users app.

  4. Select the Starter System.

  5. Upload the CSV file and click Import.

  6. Finally, click Send in order for the activation emails to be sent to all users.

 

I hope this clarifies! More information about the creation of users can be found in the Manual Creation and Authorization of Additional Users | SAP Help Portal.

The method I mentioned is a different way to fill in those source tables.  It depends on you to use which approach: use ABAP SQL to insert source table directly as sample codes of SAP Note or use standard BP source table save method as I mentioned.

For ETL (Data Services), if you have an existing BODS environment and you are familiar with this powerful tool, of course it is the best platform to extract data from various source system especially those non-SAP systems, make some transformation like data convert & merger and then load into MDC source tables.

Data services is always the most professional and powerful tool for such requirement, but you need to consider:

2. Individual environment (server, storage area...) and extra License

entry.title: Why Event-Enabling MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh is a Game Changer
entry.content:
Why Event-Enabling MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh is a Game Changer 

Introduction 

It is rare today to see a large enterprise with a monolithic system landscape; enterprises today target best of class solutions to meet the requirements of their business users, suppliers and customers.  This ever-growing landscape of heterogenous solutions increases the burden placed on integration tooling to keep their records and transactions in sync.  Lack of a true enterprise mesh to connect these applications will lead:  

  • Missing or duplicate records 
  • Data silos 
  • Out of Sync Records 
  • A fragmented view of business 

All of this will create a disjointed view of the business. Master data management is a critical function for any enterprise and requires strong coordination between business stakeholders and the IT teams that own and manage the solutions for master data.   

In today’s rapidly evolving digital landscape, data is only as powerful as its timeliness and accuracy. For organizations relying on SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to manage core business objects like Business Partners, Materials, and Cost Centers, the need for real-time data propagation across systems is more critical than ever. Traditional integration approaches often rely on batch jobs or synchronous APIs that are fragile, tightly coupled, and reactive. 

This is where event-enabling MDG—using SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) with the Event Enablement Add-On—changes the game. By embracing Event-Driven Architecture (EDA), organizations can deliver real-time, loosely coupled, and scalable master data integration across the entire business landscape.  

A study by Aberdeen research showed that 66% of organizations do not have an IT environment that is cutting edge and built to support their needs around master data integration.  What held these organizations back was:  

  • Data growing at a faster rate than they could manage and analyze it  
  • There was strong difficulty sharing and accessing data across business areas  
  • Lack of IT resources to support the growing integration needs around master data integration 

 

However, enterprises that operate in a best-in-class strategy for master data management and integration see across the board improvement in operating profit, total customer base, revenue and employee retention. 

 

Why Event-Enable MDG System? 

SAP MDG is the single source of truth for enterprise master data, but its ability to share validated changes quickly and reliably across consuming systems is key to maximizing its value. 

Challenges with traditional MDG integration: 

  • A complex spider of point-to-point synchronous integrations that require a high level of development effort for any update or change 
  • Data is out sync due to legacy methods of integration such as batch file transfer  
  • Rapidly growing system landscape new systems being onboarded all with their own methodologies for sending and receiving data  
  • Lack of a centralized view to find catalogs of master data events within the enterprise  

Event-enabling MDG solves this by: 

  • New systems can rapidly be onboarded to consume master data events without disrupting the existing integrations 
  • Organizations can easily create an event catalogue to find and filter master data events relevant to their system  
  • Point to point connections can be eliminated by adopting an event driven asynchronous architecture allowing for decoupling of all downstream systems 
  • Events can be filtered allowing downstream systems to be notified only of events they care about 
  • Updates are pushed in real time to all downstream systems when an object is created or modified  

Key Use Cases & Benefiting Systems 

Real-world scenarios where event-enabling MDG unlocks high business value 

  • Material Master Synchronization 
  • Updates to Material data in MDG can trigger: 
  • Automatic replication to production planning systems 
  • Real-time updates to supplier catalogs or inventory platforms 
  • Notifications to product lifecycle or quality teams 
  • Sync updated UPCs/EANs to all subscribing systems in real time to eliminate product returns resulting from inaccurate product data or goods not being sold at check-out due to missed scans  
  • Business Partner Integration 
  • When a Business Partner is created or updated in MDG, an event can trigger updates in: 
  • S/4HANA core and satellite systems 
  • Customer portals and CRMs (e.g., Salesforce) 
  • Identity & Access Management tools (e.g., Azure AD, Okta) 
  • Global trade systems or compliance platforms 
  • Sync updates to Business Partner information to all subscribing systems in real time to eliminate issues with wrong, outdated or missing sold to and ship to information causing delays in orders, extra shipping costs and low customer satisfaction  
  • Cost Center & Financial Master Data Distribution 
  • Replicate Cost Center changes to subscribing systems in real time such as third-party HR, External Talent Management, Manufacturing Execution Systems, Travel and Expense systems to keep accounting data current and accurate 
  • Ease the pain during mergers and acquisitions in distributing changes to chart of account information to all subscribing systems enabling consistent financial reporting 

 

 

Benefits of Using SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh with Event Add-On for MDG Integration 

The Event Enablement Add-On for MDG simplifies the process of turning master data changes into standardized events that are automatically published to SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh. 

Benefits: 

  • Automatic Event Generation 

The add-on captures and publishes master data changes as events without requiring custom coding. 

  • Seamless integration with AEM 

Events are routed through Advanced Event Mesh for real-time, reliable distribution across subscribing systems. 

  • Reduced Development Effort 

Accelerates event-driven master data integration projects by handling event creation and metadata management out of the box. 

  • Loosely Couple Architecture 

Consumers subscribe to relevant event topics without impacting MDG logic. 

  • Scalable & Resilient 

Built-in guaranteed delivery, replay, and fault tolerance via AEM. 

 

 

Extending Event-Driven Integration with SAP Integration Suite 

While SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh excels at delivering real-time events from SAP MDG & MDI, some integration scenarios require additional processing—such as data transformation, enrichment, or bridging to legacy systems that cannot consume events directly. 

SAP Integration Suite provides the ideal complement through lightweight micro-integrations (iFlows) that can handle these needs efficiently. This combined approach ensures enterprises benefit from the agility and scalability of event-driven architectures, while still addressing practical system integration requirements. 

 

Conclusion 

Event-enabling SAP MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh represents a significant leap toward real-time, intelligent master data distribution. It enables enterprises to respond faster, integrate smarter, and govern better, all while reducing integration maintenance costs. 

If you're looking to modernize how your organization distributes critical master data, it's time to move from point-to-point to event-driven. Let’s start the conversation! 

Blog Authors:  

 

 

Sumeet Koshal - Solace  

Director of EDA Solutions North America  

connect on linked in  

 

 

Cooper Walsh - SAP 

Sr. Solutions Advisor - SAP BTP

entry.title: Step-By-Step Guide: Getting started with the SAP Business Data Cloud Basic Trial
entry.content:
Want to explore and get hands-on with SAP Business Data Cloud? The basic trial is the perfect place to begin! In this blog, I’ll explain step-by-step on how to register and get started with the SAP Business Data Cloud basic trial.

What is the SAP Business Data Cloud basic trial?

Learning a new product can often feel overwhelming when you don’t know where and how to get started. Basic trials let new users get hands-on with a product and learn how about it by walking them through key workflows and core features in a guided manner.

The SAP Business Data Cloud basic trials give you free 30-day access to a guided workbook and tenant with sample data for you to learn about the foundation and capabilities included in Business Data Cloud.


Registering for the basic trial:

Follow along in this quick 2 minute video!

 

Step 1: Create your SAP Universal ID:

If you already have an SAP Universal ID, proceed to step 2.

To register for any SAP basic trial offering, all you need is an SAP Universal ID. If you do not have one yet, you will be prompted to create one. Visit https://account.sap.com/core/create/landing to get started.

Enter your details and follow the instructions to verify your account to complete the registration process. You will see a popup confirming that your SAP Universal ID has been created.

For more details, watch this video. 

Great, now that your SAP Universal ID is created, let’s get you registered for the Business Data Cloud basic trial!

Step 2: Register for the Business Data Cloud basic trial

Visit https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/trial.html and select “Try Now”.

A popup will appear with your assigned User ID and Password to access to the Business Data Cloud trial workbook and tenant. This information will also be sent to you via email.

Access the trial by clicking the hyperlink or button.

Note: Please allow 10 minutes for your user profile to generate in the SAP Business Data Cloud tenant before you try to start your basic trial.

Step 3: Sign into the basic trial

You’ll be prompted to sign into the trial by entering  your assigned User ID and Password. You can choose to stay signed in to bypass this step next time.

Once signed in, you’ll see the SAP Business Data Cloud basic trial workbook.

Click on it to access to the workbook. You’ll be taken to the workbook overview page where you can browse the modules that will be covered in the basic trial.

Step 4: Access the basic trial tenant

You will find a link in the first unit to the basic trial tenant.

You will be brought into the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. From there you can follow each unit in the workbook for a guided walkthrough of SAP Business Data Cloud.

Congratulations, you’ve succesfuly registered for the Business Data Cloud basic trial! You will have 30 days to continue learning and exploring the capabilities and features of the solution. But don’t worry, if you are unable to get through the content, you will be able to re-register for an additional 30 days of access. However, content for each 30 day period is not saved and does not carry forward.

Enjoy SAP Business Data Cloud!

entry.title: Re: Advice Needed: Best Approach for Personas Dashboard f...
entry.content:
For option 1, you could have two script buttons starting transaction VA01, populating the necessary order type and then pressing ENTER to get to the second screen of VA01.

For example, the Create Sales Order button's script would look like this:

session.callTransaction("VA01");
session.utils.changeFlavor("B7B16266416E1FD09CCE6944544F1775");
session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/ctxtVBAK-AUART").text = "OR";
session.findById("wnd[0]").sendVKey(0);
Of course, you'd change the flavor ID and order type as necessary.
You could certainly also do this starting from VA01 (by removing the first command), so the default flavor has the two buttons and then you'd switch flavor as needed.
 
As for handling these two document types with one or two separate flavors, it all depends on what fits your business process best. If those screens are significantly different between the two documents, then it is easier to go with two flavors, but if there are just minor differences on maybe one screen, then perhaps using viewports and switching between them depending on the order type makes more sense.

entry.title: Re: subcontracting with rm sold and invoiced
entry.content:
As you would know, in a standard KB PO, components move to the vendor as consignment, remain your property, and consumption is posted at zero value. No outbound billing step exists for those components—so you cannot invoice flour in the same PO.

What you can do is create a standard sales order (VA01) to sell the exact flour quantity to your processor. Deliver the flour (VL10x) and post billing (Step-1). Create your KB subcontracting PO for the pasta-making service. • Issue component (flour) from stock—this now picks up your system’s component-issue (MB1B/ME2K) against the subcontracting PO. Goods receipt of finished pasta and processing‐fee invoice from vendor.This cleanly separates the legal sale of flour (step 1) from the processing service (step 2)

You can either use one BP with both Roles, assign the party both vendor and customer roles in BP master. In VA01, pick the same BP as Sold-to; in ME21N, pick it as Vendor. Or Create Two BP Records (Recommended) as BP 1000 as Customer-Flour and BP 2000 as Vendor-Processor. The advantage of going with this approach is Clear AR vs. AP reconciliation accounts, easier audit trails (flour sales vs. processing invoices) and separate credit checks, payment terms, etc.

The below chart will give you an idea on financial postings

 

On the financial postings side, only if your chart of accounts demands distinct revenue/expense lines for regulatory reporting. Otherwise your existing sales revenue account for flour and your subcontracting expense account suffice. Account determination will happen for Sales via VKOA (condition-based GL) and on Purchase side via OBYC (movement type 101/102 for subcontracting) and your PO’s expense G/L

entry.title: cTMS Setup for SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

Many customers have already begun adopting SAP Datasphere on BTP, migrating their on-premise analytics landscape to the cloud. In traditional on-premise BW systems, moving developments across the landscape is straightforward using STMS. However, with Datasphere being cloud-native, you might be wondering how to manage and transport your developments while maintaining proper change control. This is where Cloud TMS comes in. It enables you to transport content seamlessly across your cloud landscape, ensuring alignment with change management processes. Let’s dive deeper into how Cloud TMS can be set up and start using it effectively.

cTMS Architecture – SAP Datasphere

Here we have four environments Dev, QA, UAT, and Prod, each corresponding to a separate BTP subaccount. We have provisioned the Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) in a separate subaccount. The Datasphere team develop/configure various content packages and export the same from the Dev Datasphere tenant using Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS), which then adds the transport to the QA node. From there, it is imported into QA and the subsequent environments (UAT, Prod) through Solution Manager (SolMan), leveraging Focused Build (FB) or Charm status transitions.

Additionally, this setup can be integrated with SAP Cloud ALM

Setup Steps:

Since several of these SaaS applications share common setup steps, please begin by following the initial setup steps outlined here Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Step1: Setup OAuth Client in Datasphere

To enable integration with cTMS using Destinations, you must set up an OAuth client in each SAP Datasphere tenant.

Login to SAP Datasphere (DSP) and follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to:
    System > Administration > App Integration > OAuth Clients

  2. Click on "Configure Clients"

  3. Select "Add a New OAuth Client" to create a new client configuration.

Name: Give appropriate name
Purpose: API Access
Access: Analytical Content Network Interaction
Security: Client credentials
Token lifetime: by default 1 hour, you can extend it up to 24 hrs. 

Note: Make sure to copy and securely store the Client ID and Client Secret.
The Client Secret will not be visible again after you click Add. 

Step2: Create Destinations to DSP Tenants

In the subaccount where the Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) service is subscribed, create a destination to each target SAP Datasphere Tenant. 

Name: Give appropriate name to resemble your CTMS Node

URL:https://<DSPTenant>.<region>.hcs.cloud.sap/api/v1/content/deploy/

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: https://<DSPTenant>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

Use the Client id and Secret you setup in step1 above in Datasphere tenant. 

Step3: Configure Transport Nodes in cTMS

Prerequisites

  • You have been assigned one of the following roles: Administrator or LandscapeOperator.

From the cTMS UI, you can define transport nodes to represent your system landscape. There are multiple ways to create a node:

You can either Create a node on the Landscape Visualization screen or from Transport Nodes screen. 

Allow Upload to Node: Enable this checkbox to allow file uploads to the node. Enabled for the Dev node only. 

Forward Mode: Default value is Auto, You can change this setting based on your landscape and transport flow requirements.

Controlled by SAP Solution Manager: Select this checkbox only if you plan to integrate with SAP Solution Manager (e.g., Charm or Focused Build). We will only enable this for QA and upper environments.  When you enable this, it will not allow manual imports from cTMS UI, only through Charm/FB status change. 

Note: If you plan to integrate with Cloud ALM, do not check this option. 

Content Type: For Datasphere, select Application Content.

Destination: Select the appropriate target destination you previously configured in your cTMS subaccount in Step2.

Step4: Create Transport routes in cTMS

In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

Name: Provide the appropriate name

Chose the Source node & Target node and click on OK. 

Your landscape loos like this

Note: You can also use Transport Landscape Wizard, with which you can setup the all your landscape nodes & routes at a time.

Step5: DSP Configuration

To enable cTMS integration in SAP Datasphere, you have to connect it to cTMS by following these steps:

  1. Log in to the Dev SAP Datasphere tenant

  2. Go to: Transport → Export

  3. Navigate to the Content Network Storage tab and select My Content

  4. In the menu bar, click Settings

  5. Upload the cTMS service key (in JSON format)

  6. Once successfully uploaded, the status will change to Live, indicating that the integration is active

Now the option to upload content to cTMS becomes available.

  • Select the content package(s) you want to transport

  • Click the "Upload to cTMS" option to export the content to Cloud Transport Management Service

This will initiate the transport process and push the selected content to the configured QA node.

Step6: Integrate with Solution Manager

To integrate Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) with SAP Solution Manager (Charm / Focused Build), follow the step6 from below article. 

If you want to integrate with Cloud ALM, follow the step7 from below article. 

 Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Conclusion:

I hope you have learned, how to setup cTMS for SAP Datasphere. Now the setup is complete and ready for transporting the content using cTMS either integrated with SAP Solution Manager or Cloud ALM.

Thank you for reading  my article, feel free to provide any feedback or comment for any questions.

Thanks,
Raghu

entry.title: Re: Material is managed under standard price control in o...
entry.content:
Some of the impacts would be

  • Standard Price vs. MAP
    Goods movements post at the standard price, so inventory valuation and postings remain at the set standard.
  • But any processes or ledger calculations that reference the MAP now use zero—leading to distorted variances and consumption values.


Purchase Price Variances

  • Every purchase receipt compares the invoice price to the standard price and posts the difference to price-difference G/L accounts.
  • Overwriting MAP to zero inflates these variances when you later run actual costing or revaluation.


Material Ledger Actual Costing

  • Actual costing (periodic ML settlement) allocates the zero MAP as the “actual price,” generating massive negative variances versus standard.
  • Inventory revaluation at period-end will swing heavily into COGS or variance accounts.


Statistical Consumption & Forecasting

  • Quantity × MAP becomes zero in statistical reports (e.g., MC.1), so your consumption value history collapses.
  • Any MRP or planning logic that uses statistical key figures for value-based heuristics will be thrown off.

The below chart will explain Reports & Tools Highlighting Discrepancies

Downstream Effects on COPA - If you run quantity‐based costing or use actual cost for margin, zero MAP yields zero cost in profitability analyses: massively overstating contribution margins.

Downstream Effects on COGS reporting - Standard–price issues still post COGS at the standard price, so day-to-day COGS stays true. But period-end revaluations to actual cost (if active) will skew COGS and inventory adjustments far off the mark.

Downstream Effects on Intercompany Transfer Pricing - If your internal procurement logic pulls from MAP, internal billing documents will pick up a zero price—leading to zero intercompany revenue/cost. Consolidation and elimination entries will then require extensive manual corrections.


So your next step  be

  • Identify affected materials via CKM3 or MB5B (MAP = 0).
  • Reset MAP: use MR21 or post a reversal/receipt cycle to restore the correct average price.
  • Re‐run period‐end ML settlement (CKMLCP) to clear out aberrant variances.
  • Prevent future zero‐MAP edits with a master‐data validation (user exit or BAdI).
  • Reconcile price‐difference G/Ls (transaction F.5G) and verify your CO-PA margins against expected standards.

entry.title: Re: How to calculate depreciation for multiple capitalizations across years in SAC?
entry.content:
Hi @nasser_itani

To clarify your request:

  1. Please map the ID and description of the Capex account members.
    For example: CAPEX_003 = Total Budget
  2. Please provide the attribute information of the Project dimension ([d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT]).
    For example: [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/ENERGIZEDYEAR] = ?
  3. Is the Budget column represented by [d/DIM_BUDGETYEAR]?
  4. How can we determine the @USEFULLIFE value? Is it retrieved from an attribute value or provided as an input parameter? It seems to be 30 Years for your current example. 
  5. Is the currently provided table the expected result? If not, please provide the expected result in a table format.

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: Automatically mark process flow indicators in a purch...
entry.content:
Some available options are

  • For Delivery Completed go to SPRO → Materials Management → Purchasing → Purchase Order → Delivery Completed Indicator. Define tolerances (e.g. 0–0% over/under-delivery) and activate automatic “Delivery Completed” when cumulative GR qty ≥ PO qty.
  • For Final Invoice Indicator, go to SPRO → Materials Management → Logistics Invoice Verification → Invoice → Final Invoice. Enable “Automatic Final Invoice” for PO items with no open delivery/invoice quantity.
  • For GR-Based Invoice Verification, it is is driven by the invoice verification process itself: if you do a MIRO against a PO item, SAP will automatically set the GR-Based Invoice Verification flag. No extra config needed beyond standard IV tolerance settings (tolerances in SPRO under Invoice Verification).

entry.title: Re: Where to find Customer scope item BGI-Customer Projec...
entry.content:
No idea about official statement but below are the authoritative places to verify that Customer Project Analysis (BGI) has been absorbed into newer scope items.

In SAP Roadmap Explorer (roadmapexplorer.sap.com), search for “Customer Project Analysis.” The system will show the lifecycle of that scope item. If it’s marked as superseded or retired, the replacement scope items are listed.

Open the SAP Best Practices Explorer for your target release (for example, 2302 or 2402). In the filter panel, search for “Customer Project Analysis” or scope item ID “BGI-…”. If it no longer appears, its functionality has formally been removed or replaced.

entry.title: End-to-End Performance Testing of SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, Kyma and ABAP Environment based Application
entry.content:
1. Introduction

We shall discuss the SAP BTP introduction, purpose, and scope of this technical article.

SAP BTP is a collection of SAP solutions and services housed under one roof. These services and solutions assist organisations in developing a new cloud solution or expanding will discuss or expanding SAP systems.

SAP BTP's services and solutions are organised around four main pillars. They are as follows:

  1. Database & Data Management

You can use this pillar to store, access, process, integrate, and interpret all of your landscape's data.

      2. Analytics

The analytics pillar's products enable you to plan, forecast, and make quick, insight-driven decisions.

     3. Application Development & Integration

The application development and integration pillar provide the core elements required to innovate, extend, and integrate agile business processes in the cloud and hybrid environments. You can rapidly integrate other systems, improve your current application, or create new business solutions.

    4. Intelligent Technologies

Artificial intelligence, machine learning, intelligent robotic process automation, blockchain, and the Internet of Things are all part of the intelligent technologies pillar. This will assist you in automating the difficult, repetitive decisions that comprise a substantial component of company processes.

 

SAP Business Technology Platform is technically classified as a Platform-as-a-Service. SAP BTP offers three environments: Cloud Foundry, ABAP and Kyma. All of these environments allow you to use different programming language and provide a ready-made framework for building and deploying any cloud service.

 

Image Source: SAP, links are provided in the reference section#SAP Business Technology Platform Concepts.

2.1 Objective

The objective of this technical article is to provide a comprehensive framework for performance testing/engineering of applications developed and integrated within the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). With the increasing adoption of BTP as a pivotal platform for application development and integration, it becomes essential to establish a robust performance testing process that addresses the unique challenges posed by this ecosystem. This article aims to outline the key pillars of the performance testing process while focusing on the application development and integration aspect of SAP BTP.

SAP BTP offers three key environments: Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and ABAP.

Each environment includes the tools, technologies, and runtimes required to build applications.

  1. Cloud Foundry Environment

You can create business apps using the Cloud Foundry platform, which supports numerous runtimes, programming languages, libraries, and services.

      2. ABAP Environment

The ABAP environment enables you to construct new cloud apps and extensions for ABAP-based products such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Existing ABAP-based custom code or extensions can be converted to the cloud.

     3. Kyma Environment

The Kyma environment is a fully managed Kubernetes runtime that is based on the open-source project "Kyma" that enables developers to augment SAP systems with serverless functions and combine them with containerized microservices.

2.2 Scope

Performance testing for applications developed in different environments within the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) requires tailored approaches to address the distinct characteristics of each scenario. This scoping outlines the methodologies for conducting performance testing for applications built with the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry/Kyma environment and the ABAP environment.

This technical article will considerably add to the body of information addressing the performance characteristics of applications deployed on Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and the ABAP Environment within the SAP Business Technology Platform. The insights will assist enterprises in making educated decisions when picking the optimum runtime for their specific application workloads based on business requirements and performance optimization approaches.

  1. Methodology to configure and monitor performance statistics of BTP Cloud Foundry/KYMA based application using Dynatrace.

Dynatrace provides a powerful APM (Application Performance Monitoring) solution that is perfectly suited to the dynamic and cloud-native nature of SAP Business Technology Platform applications. Its AI-powered insights, comprehensive monitoring capabilities, and ease of integration make it an excellent solution for assuring optimal performance.

Dynatrace allows you to monitor your entire infrastructure, including hosts, processes, and networks.

Dynatrace can monitor Microservices, Docker, Kubernetes, Cloud Foundry, and other technologies-based applications.

 

 

Image Source: SAP, links are provided in the reference section# Dynatrace Agent Activation for SAP BTP.

 

3.1. Steps to Create a user provided Dynatrace service in your SAP BTP Environment:

  1. Add the SAP Dynatrace Monitoring Service entitlement to your BTP Global Account.

 

Image Source: SAP BTP Control Center – My Global Account

2. Configure the SAP Dynatrace Monitoring Service entitlement at the Subaccount level.

 

Image Source: SAP BTP Cockpit - My Sub Account

3. Navigate to the Service Marketplace and look for SAP Dynatrace Monitoring Service.

 

Image Source: SAP BTP Cockpit - My Sub Account

 

You must supply a valid JSON object containing at least the environmentid and apitoken(for Dynatrace SaaS). The API token relates to the PaaS token. For Dynatrace Managed, you must also include the apiurl argument, which specifies the Dynatrace API endpoint.

 

Image Source: Dynatrace, links are provided in the reference section# Dynatrace Agent Activation for SAP BTP.

Remark:

In case you face challenge to create Dynatrace service please see section#3.4: Real-time issues while creating a Dynatrace service. 

SAMPLE JSON:

All Dynatrace instances are linked with the SAP Cloud Access Manager (CAM) and Single-Sign On, in accordance with best practises and SAP-compliant access management systems.

 

A CAM Profile is a set of access levels to multiple SAP systems and environments.

 

You can also create your own standard practice to safeguard your mission critical business data.

 

{

  "apiurl": "https://DYNATRACE HOST NAME/e/ENVIRONMENT ID/api",

  "apitoken": "YOUR PASS TOKEN",

  "environmentid": "ENVIRONMENT ID",

  "permission_assignments": [

    {

      "name": "CAM1 Read-only access to the Dynatrace environment",

      "roles": [

        "log_analytics",

        "user"

      ]

    },

    {

      "name": "CAM2 Read and Write access to the Dynatrace environment and all settings (except request attributes and sensitive data)",

      "roles": [

        "admin",

        "configure_sensitive",

        "log_analytics",

        "view_sensitive"

 

        "name": "CAM3: Write access to request attribute settings and view permission of masked sensitive data",

      "roles": [

 

        "configure_sensitive",

        "view_sensitive"

      ]

    }

  ]

}

 

Dynatrace Agent Activation:

 

Image Source: Dynatrace, links are provided in the reference section# Dynatrace Agent Activation for SAP BTP.

3.2 Bind the Created Dynatrace service with the application deployed in BTP Environment (Cloud Foundry/KYMA – JAVA/SAP CAP/Microservice etc)

Configure service instance in application's mta.yaml/manifest.yml file

 

Sample mta.yml file

Add following sample code in resources of modules

resources:

 

- name: dynatrace-demo

  type: org.cloudfoundry.existing-service

 

Add the service in requires section of the Modules to be monitored.

 

requires:

  - name:

    dynatrace-monitor

 

Sample manifest.yml file

---

applications:

- name: spring-music

  memory: 768M

  instances: 1

  host: spring-music-somerandomstring

  path: spring-music.war

  buildpack: sap_java_buildpack

  services:

  - dynatraceservice

 

3.3 Restart your BTP deployed JAVA/SAP CAP etc application and login to Dynatrace environment and monitor/search your binded application

 

Image Source: DYNATRACE Managed - My Environment

3.4: Real-time issues while creating a Dynatrace service

Even after following all the above steps, sometimes you might face challenge to find your binded application name in the Dynatrace monitoring environment or you will not be able to create the Dynatrace service, please follow below steps using Cloud foundry CLI:

  •  Sometimes a restart of the BTP deployed application (JAVA/SAP CAP) is not enough, it needs to be a restage (only during staging the Dynatrace agent will be downloaded). Please restage your application and see if the process shows up after maximum 3 minutes in the Dynatrace environment.

 

  • You can try renaming/creating your Dynatrace service to something containing “dynatrace”, e.g.

 

cf create-service dynatrace environment test-dynatrace -c <JSON> file //keep only relevant configuration in JSON file.

 

  • and then bind the application and restage again.

 

              cf bind-service my-application test-dynatrace

 

  1. Methodology to configure and monitor performance statistics of BTP ABAP environment-based application.

SAP introduced an exciting addition to SAP BTP, which they aptly named SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Steampunk or ABAP Cloud. This innovative feature opens a world of possibilities for customers, partners who are well-versed in ABAP:

With the ABAP Environment, they can effortlessly harness the power of ABAP Platform as a service within SAP BTP. This means they can:

  1. Craft extensions for ABAP-based products like SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Pave the way for the creation of brand-new cloud applications.

Now, let's delve into some key aspects of the ABAP Environment:

  1. This environment operates on the latest ABAP platform cloud release.
  2. It boasts support for the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model, which includes popular components like SAP Fiori and Core Data Services (CDS).

Now in order to monitor and analyse the performance of ABAP cloud-based application, you need to have the access of the Frontend (Say SAP Fiori), backend (say SAP ABAP GUI) and ADT(ABAP Development Tools)

Front End Access:

 

                                                                 Image Source: developers.sap.com

  1. You can login to the Fiori launchpad using Administrator user and access the Maintain employees/Maintain business users Fiori application to create a new user and also to assign a specific role to access the relevant application under performance evaluation.

 

Backend Access:

Now in order to access the backend, administrator should create a backend user and generate credentials for you.

Once the backend user is created in the ABAP cloud environment, you can access your application using SAP GUI(/NSTFK) or create your custom SAP GUI configuration file and save it locally with. sap extension.

YourApplicationSID.sap configuration:

Pass the required details and execute the file using double click to access your backend application with the created credentials:

        

 

                                  

                  Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

ABAP Development Tools (ADT)

  1. Install ADT
  2. Add a new ABAP Cloud Project

 

 

 

       Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

Now you can make connection to ABAP service instance using any suitable mention ways:

 

                                                            Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

  1. Pass the service key in JSON format:

 

 

                                Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

 

  1. Open Logon in browser:

 

                                    Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

  1. Access with a valid sign in option:

 

 

                                      Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

 

  1. You will receive success message in the browser:

 

 

                                  Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

 

  1. Now you can analyse your underlying ABAP model.

 

 

                                    Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

Remark: Sometimes you face challenge to access ABAP service instance through ADT, you can clear the browser cache or review your VPN settings to see if it is working or not, also you can refer the helpful blog mention in the reference section.   

 

  1. Performance analysis/engineering of BTP based applications: Automated/Manual Approach

5.1 BTP Applications running in Cloud Foundry / Kyma Environment (Runtime) and are binded with DYNATRACE APM tool:

 

Let’s consider one scenario where one of the web application action - Click Go Operation was expensive (consuming higher response time/resource).

User Action: Click on Go with suitable Filter condition.

 

                                                                   Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

Final Render Page:

 

                                                                 Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

 

Chrome Developer Trace: F12-Network Trace->We can see one expensive http request taking higher time.

 

 

                                                                  Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

Let see how we can analyse or do the root cause analysis of this expensive request.

  1. Firstly, with the help of Chrome – Network/Profiling Developer Trace(F12), we can get more details about the request, response payload and API endpoint.

     

                                                                      Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

      2.Now login to your DYNATRACE cluster, and try to find your underlying service(let say OrderProposal* is my underlying microservice), you can see details about the health of your microservice

 

                                                          Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

 

    3. Now our task would be to identify the expensive request hitting to this microservice, you can get the details using View Distributed Traces/Pure Paths, filter the request based on service name and time frame of the test, you can configure column to get more information about the expensive application call(like getOrderProposal calls for Go Operation)

 

 

                                                        Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

    4. You have several features inside Dynatrace to perform root cause analysis for any application performance issues like:

 

View response time hotspots: Analyses the response time of each service per process.

View method hotspots: Shows the CPU level hotspots in your code.

View service flow: Shows the chain of service calls that each service request initiates.

View details of failures: Displays extensive statistics on site request failures.

View Service backtrace: Displays which user actions and related services depend on this service.

 

 

                                                        Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

5. Click on the request name (say getOrderProposals): Most of the time spent on execution

 

 

                                                              Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

   6. Click Response time hotspots: Most of the time is spent on service interaction.

 

 

                                                        Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

    7. Click on Method Hotspots: OncePerRequestFilter is the Top method.

 

                                                          Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

  8. You can click on source code to analyse it from code perspective:

 

 

                                                       Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

 

                                                                      Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

 

Remark:

Similarly, you can monitor all other important performance KPI’s for your Kubernetes, Cloud Foundry based application for all your single user and multiuser performance test.

 

                                                                Image Source: Internal Infrastructure

5.2 BTP Applications running in ABAP Environment (Runtime)

Let’s consider one scenario where one of the web application user action - Click Open App was expensive (consuming higher response time/resource).

  1. Open App - User Action: Click on App Tile

                

               

 

 2.  Final Render Page Screen:

 

3. Take Chrome – Developer Trace(F12) -> Network Trace ->To understand the expensive request/response payload coming from Open App User Action

 

4. Now login to ABAP backend instance and use transaction /OSTATS_FE with Filter condition on Time, Fiori Frontend user name and system client.

5. Now you can find all the relevant expensive request and its key performance KPI’s made from the front-end web application (Check for column Frontend Step Name), you can double click on any expensive request to see further breakdown(server side metrics/expensive calls):

 

 

6. Now we understood, Open App user action response time was higher due to one expensive http batch request.

 

7. As a next step we collected the ADT Trace (ABAP Profiler) to understand the issue from code perspective:

 

8. We found that one expensive *query_provider* method causing higher response time.

 

 

 

 

 

 

  1. Proposed solution for automating the performance monitoring process of ABAP Environment based applications:

 Architecture:

 

                                                                          Image Source: Self creation

Monitoring the ABAP environment can be integrated into your existing infrastructure if you utilise SAP Cloud ALM as your monitoring and alerting infrastructure. You may also use SAP Cloud ALM's health monitoring to see if your ABAP environment is still up and running and if any unusual events have occurred. Furthermore, you can utilise real-user monitoring to monitor requests from business users and integration monitoring to monitor interactions across integrated systems.

You can also look for other feasible solution available for specific ABAP environment-based application performance monitoring like Grafana/ABAP Open telemetry(data provider).

 

  1. SAP AI Core service to assist customers and end-users with performance testing and analysis of applications built on SAP BTP

As organisations rely more on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for application development, optimising performance becomes critical to providing a consistent user experience. Taking advantage of SAP AI Core's major features inside the BTP ecosystem provides a strategic approach to improving performance testing and analysis.

7.1 We can achieve this by building a ML Model/GenAI/Agents based PoC using SAP AI Core Services to have below functionalities:

 7.1.2.Data-Driven Performance Evaluation:

Utilise the data intelligence of SAP AI Core to collect and analyse huge datasets relevant to application performance. This data-driven methodology enables comprehensive performance testing scenarios that consider a wide range of user interactions and usage patterns within the SAP BTP environment.

       7.1.2. Anomaly Detection in Real-Time:

Integrate the anomaly detection capabilities of SAP AI Core to provide real-time monitoring of performance indicators. The technology may detect anomalous patterns automatically, offering rapid insight into potential bottlenecks or issues influencing the end-user experience.

     3. Scalability Predictive Analytics:

Using historical data, use SAP AI Core's predictive analytics to forecast scaling difficulties. This proactive strategy supports in resource optimisation and minimising potential performance bottlenecks before they affect end users.

     4. Intelligent Testing Automation:

Use SAP AI Core's intelligent automation features to generate complicated test scenarios and scripts automatically. This shortens the performance testing lifecycle and allows for a more detailed examination of application performance under different conditions.

    5. Simulation of User Behaviour:

Using SAP AI Core's behaviour simulation, mimic real-world user behaviours. Performance testing becomes more typical of actual usage patterns when realistic user scenarios are created, enabling for the detection of performance issues that may affect end users.

    6. AI-Assisted Root Cause Analysis:

Use the analytics tools in SAP AI Core for root cause analysis. When performance issues are found, the system may automatically analyse correlated data to determine the root causes, allowing for faster issue resolution and optimisation.

   7. Continuous Optimisation and Adaptation:

Create a continuous improvement loop by upgrading AI models on a regular basis with new performance data. This guarantees that the system adapts to changing application parameters, ensuring consistency in performance testing and analysis.

Organisations may not only streamline their performance testing processes but also improve the overall reliability and responsiveness of SAP BTP-based applications by strategically combining SAP BTP with SAP AI Core's main capabilities. This strategy adds to a better user experience, which aligns with the SAP BTP platform's primary objectives of delivering high-quality, efficient solutions.

  1. Conclusions

Finally, this research article has provided valuable insights into the realm of performance testing/engineering for individual developers, testers and customers within diverse Business Technology Platform (BTP) environments including Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and ABAP. The importance of performance testing cannot be overstated in today's dynamic digital landscape, where applications must deliver optimal user experiences to remain competitive.

We have not only defined the fundamental concepts and principles of performance testing through painstaking examination, but we have also provided practical advice on how individual developers, testers and customers can navigate the complexities of testing in these diverse BTP environments. Our findings highlight the need of customised performance testing methodologies, emphasising the necessity for a nuanced approach that matches with the unique characteristics and expectations of each platform.

Furthermore, this study showed the benefits and problems of performance testing on Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and ABAP, putting light on the unique characteristics and restrictions of each environment. We have provided developers, testers and customers with the information and resources needed to optimise application performance in these contexts by reviewing real-world case studies and best practises.

The ability to conduct efficient performance testing on various BTP platforms has become a vital talent in an era of constant technological innovation. As the enterprise solution landscape evolves, the insights presented in this article will be a valuable resource, empowering developers, testers and customers to improve the performance, reliability, and scalability of their applications and ensuring their continued success in a highly competitive marketplace. We can together design a future where applications running on Cloud Foundry, Kyma, ABAP environment and beyond continuously deliver great performance, promoting innovation and efficiency in the digital domain, through collaborative efforts and ongoing research.

entry.title: Re: Batch Jobs for processing Billing document of Billing...
entry.content:
Use Schedule Billing Document Request Creation (Service Contract) (App F1522) in a nightly job so that all open billing‐eligible lines are converted into BDRs. Service Contracts must be in Released status with open billing plan lines.
From Fiori Launchpad, open Schedule Billing Creation (App F1519). Click Create to define a new background job.
In the Selection Criteria section of your new job definition, enter the Document category, Billing type, Reference Document (optional but recommended), Sales Organization / Distribution Channel / Division (to narrow down to the sales org parameters that your service contracts use). If your service contracts don’t use Sales-Org / Channel / Division, you can leave them blank and rely solely on the Reference Document filter. Schedule the job by midnight daily of weekly depending upon the Business requirement.

Confirm that BDRs exist (run the “Billing Due List” app and filter by Contract number). Check the Reference Document Type is set to CR, not blank. If invoices are being created directly (bypassing BDRs): Ensure you did not select “Sales Order” or “Deliveries” in Document Category. Avoid using billing type BDS (order‐based billing) or blank in the Billing Type field.

entry.title: Re: Manage payments for import purchases
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition you can leverage the Import Shipment object to collect all POs for one physical shipment. Once the POs “belong” to a shipment, you can run your payment/advance‐payment proposal against that shipment instead of individual POs.

You can use Standard Import–Procurement Apps (Scope Item 1UD/1UB). Open the Fiori tile Import Shipments – Manage (app ID: F4198 or similar). Click Create and enter your shipment details (Shipment ID, Incoterms, Port of Entry, etc.), in the Assigned Purchase Orders section, add all POs that belong to this shipment. You can search by PO number, vendor, date, etc. Save the shipment. All POs now carry the shipment reference. You can monitor status (Customs Declaration, Goods Receipt) in Import Shipments – Track.
You can drive Payments by Shipment. Use the Fiori tile Manage Automatic Payments (app ID: F1117). Create a new payment proposal, but in the Selection section filter by Shipment ID instead of PO number. Execute the run. The system will pick up all open payables tied to that shipment. Approve and post your global payment or down‐payment for the full shipment in one step.

You often need to assign import costs (customs fees, freight forwarding, brokerage) to different service providers in your POs. SAP S/4HANA Cloud delivers an offline mass‐change app for purchasing info records—use it to update all your condition records in one shot. Launch the Mass Changes to Purchasing Info Records Fiori app (app ID: F1758). Click Download Template and select the Info Records you want to update (by vendor or material). In Excel: Locate the Pricing tab—here you’ll see all condition types (e.g., FGW1 for freight, CFxx for customs). For each condition line, populate the Pricing Partner (your customs agent/freight forwarder) and adjust rates as needed. Save and Upload the completed workbook back into the app. Review the preview, then activate. All condition‐record updates are committed.

In short, the summary is

entry.title: Re: Issues Debugging SAP MDK on Windows with Android Emul...
entry.content:
I always use Attach on Android for my debugging but when doing this I also have a terminal window open where I have executed ns run android --emulator --no-hmr and the command is still running providing console output to the terminal.  In this scenario when I run the Build Task from within VS Code it copies the updated bundle to the client and because the ns run is still active in the terminal window it relaunches the client.  The downside is that the relaunch will disconnect the debugger.  As a result I typically use App Update an deploy from VSCode to App Update and Check for Updates in my client to pickup the changes.  This does not disconnect the existing debugger.

Regarding the typing in the debug console terminating the session this is something we are aware of and working to find a solution.   The Debug Console does support dynamic input during paused breakpoints in MDK/NativeScript apps.  This is currently only affecting Android (on both Windows and Mac) in the more recent versions..  The workaround is to paste the statement you want to execute into the debug console.  Then it works as expected.  So I am currently opening a new tab as a scratch pad to type out commands to copy and paste into the debug console if it isn't something I can copy and paste directly from the source code view.

Hope this helps.

Bill

entry.title: Re: comparison scripting
entry.content:
Instead of using two dropdown , I would suggest as following: 

  1. Create two restricted measures by using two different version input control 
  2. Create a calculated measure to calculate the variance between two restricted measures. 
  3. Show only the calculated measure in column

entry.title: Re: Certain number of POs that are missing the date line...
entry.content:
The symptom you are seeing, certain POs coming up in ME21N with incorrect or missing entries on the Date Line tab, and it only happening sporadically in production, points to an issue outside standard SAP copy logic. It could be a user‐exit/BAdI enhancement, a background program or interface (IDoc/BAPI), or even Foreign Trade (FMS) customizing driving those date‐fields.

In ME21N or ME23N, pick one PO with correct date lines and one PO with wrong date lines. In SE16N, display table EKPO for both POs, focusing on fields like Schedule line date (EKPO–EINDT), Delivery date (EKPO–LFDAT) and Creation date (EKPO–AEDAT). Display the schedule line details in EKET for each PO item. Check if wrong POs have extra or missing entries in EKET. Note any differences in table EKKO header dates (BEDAT, ERDAT). This comparison highlights whether the bad POs carried unexpected schedule‐line data from the start or were altered after save.

The suspected areas would be any customer-specific logic in copy routines (LMEPO004, LMEPO005) can modify schedule lines. BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST (method PROCESS_ITEM or PROCESS_HEADERS) or User‐exit EXIT_SAPMM06E_012 (could manipulate date lines).

So, to trouble shoot this error, what you can do is to analyze the issue in debug mode after executing ME21N. Set a breakpoint in ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST~PROCESS_ITEM. Create a test PO (in a QAS using prod‐like data) that historically failed in production. Step through every enhancement to see who writes to EKPO–EINDT.

Trace the good and bad PO creations in parallel. Filter on tables EKPO/EKET to catch which ABAP include or function module triggers the write.

In WE02/WE05, find any inbound messages for the problematic POs. See if date‐segment (e.g., E1POMHDR) is missing or has wrong dates.

entry.title: Re: Proof of delivery -OVER exception
entry.content:
By default SAP only lets you confirm up to the exact delivered (or GR’d) quantity. Anything over is treated as an error unless you give yourself some breathing room via tolerance. To fix this, go to SPRO → Sales and Distribution → Basic Functions → Delivery Processing → Tolerances for delivery → Under/Over-delivery tolerance. Give yourself an Over-delivery tolerance (for example 25%). A 25% tolerance on 4 pieces lets you confirm up to 5 pieces. Once you’ve increased the over-delivery tolerance, the POD app will let you record 5 pieces as an OVER exception.

If you’re in Decentralized or embedded EWM and you pick an exception code like I003/O003 (No Quantity Adjustment), the system will refuse to bump the shipment/inbound delivery above the 4-piece original. Go to SPRO > Extended Warehouse Mgmt → Cross-Process Settings → Delivery – Warehouse Request → Process Codes → Define Process Codes. For your EWM process‐code profile pick the code that says “Adjustment of Delivery Quantity” or “Adjustment of Delivery Quantity and Document” (I001/O001 or I002/O002, depending on your release). Make sure that process code is assigned to your inbound/outbound delivery type. Now when you run POD and pick that process code, EWM will actually adjust the delivery to 5 pieces—then let the POD OVER exception go through.

Proof-of-Delivery is purely a confirmation step. If you truly want the system to know “5 pieces arrived,” you either must. Post a second GR (MIGO/101) for the extra piece so the inbound delivery goes to 5, or Change the delivery schedule lines manually in VL32N (inbound) or VL02N (outbound) before you do POD. Only after the delivery document itself shows 5 pieces will the POD OVER exception let you confirm that quantity.

entry.title: Re: how to correct condition amount in closed sales order...
entry.content: If no Accounting document is not generated for that billing document, system would allow you to update the pricing and tax, assuming you have a valid condition records for that.  If an Accounting Document is generated, then, you need to cancel the billing document via vf11 and recreate with right tax value

entry.title: Re: Coping Price from Inquiry to Quotation in Public cloud
entry.content:
When you reference an Inquiry (document type AG) to create a Quotation (AQ) in Public Cloud, the system always redetermines pricing by design. The copy control “Pricing Type” field is delivered in display-only mode, so you can’t switch it from “R” (redetermine) to “A” (copy without redetermine) in standard configuration.

In SAP Public Cloud, Inquiries are meant for customer information and don’t persist price conditions. When you create a Quotation, the system always runs the full pricing procedure. It is recommended to skip the Inquiry step for pure pricing needs. Use the Manage Sales Quotations app to build your quote with live pricing. This aligns to public-cloud best practice and avoids any copy-control limitation.

If you must capture a price in the Inquiry and carry it into the Quotation, extend the solution as follows:

Use the “Custom Fields and Logic” Fiori app. Create a new field (e.g., ZINQ_PRICE) on Inquiry Header/Item UIs. Enhance the Inquiry creation screen to populate ZINQ_PRICE from your pricing simulation. Save the Inquiry so ZINQ_PRICE is stored. In “Custom Fields and Logic,” subscribe to the SalesDocumentItemCopy business event. This transfers ZINQ_PRICE into a new field on the Quotation (you’ll need to expose that too). Add your new custom field to the Quotation UI. Optionally, use another custom logic to feed ZINQ_PRICE into the Quotation’s condition table or pricing simulation. This approach doesn’t unlock the hidden “Pricing Type” toggle but gives you control to carry an Inquiry price forward.
